Perched in pairs on mantelpieces across the nation by the end of the 19th century, these earthenware figurines depicting gold-collared spaniels and other dogs embody both a fantasy of rarefied country life — Queen Victoria’s beloved pet Dash was a Cavalier King Charles — and the population’s conformist tastes. Indeed, the pieces were among the most sought-after designs, along with delicate floral-patterned bone-china tea sets and intricate neo-Classical jasperware vases produced by the Potteries, the group of pioneering factories, eventually numbering in the hundreds, established in the 17th century in the coal-mining towns that form the present-day city of Stoke-on-Trent. title: Should the American Theater Take French Lessons?
description: Arts workers are protesting closings and occupying playhouses all over France. On Broadway, that drama has yet to open.
content: The only march you’re likely to see on Broadway this year is the kind with trombones in “The Music Man.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Abrams
title: ‘The Falcon and the Winter Soldier’: What You Need to Know
description: The heroes of this new Disney+ series share a complex relationship that has evolved over multiple films within the Marvel Cinematic Universe. Here are the most crucial bits of history and context.
content: Two faithful sidekicks become leads in “The Falcon and the Winter Soldier,” a new superhero series premiering Friday on Disney+. This show takes place some time after “Avengers: Endgame,” when the newly retired super-soldier Steve Rogers (Chris Evans) announces his retirement as the patriotic hero Captain America. Rogers also gives his red, white and blue Vibranium metal shield to Sam Wilson (Anthony Mackie), a retired Air Force veteran who as “The Falcon” flies around with a jet-powered winged harness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Poverty as a Proxy for Race in Voter Suppression
description: Because Black people vote overwhelmingly for Democrats, Republicans don’t want as many Black people to vote.
content: You just can’t be racist the way you used to.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall
title: Endangered Gazelles Make a Comeback on the Edge of a War Zone
description: Hunted nearly to extinction worldwide, a wild mountain gazelle finds a helping hand on the Turkish-Syrian border.
content: KIRIKHAN, Turkey — Turkey’s southern border with Syria has become a place of hardship and misery, with tented camps for people displaced by a decade of war on the Syrian side and a concrete wall blocking entrance to Turkey for all but the most determined.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Barbara Rickles, Comedian’s Wife and Target, Dies at 84
description: Don Rickles made jokes about her for decades. But by many accounts, they had one of the happiest marriages in show business.
content: Barbara Rickles, the widow of the comedian Don Rickles and a fictionalized target of his comic insults, died on Sunday, which would have been their 56th wedding anniversary, at her home in Los Angeles. She was 84.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson and Ben Shpigel
title: Deshaun Watson Accused of Sexual Assault in Civil Suits
description: Lawsuits filed Tuesday and Wednesday accused the Houston Texans quarterback of misconduct during massages last year. Watson said in a statement Tuesday that he had never “treated any woman with anything other than the utmost respect.”
content: Deshaun Watson, the star quarterback of the Houston Texans, has been accused of sexually assaulting two massage therapists last year, according to two civil suits filed this week in Harris County, Texas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Wilson
title: The Mansion Is Closed Because of Covid. No One Told the Deer.
description: Barrington Court, a grand estate in England that was a filming site for “Wolf Hall,” has been shut to visitors for much of the last year — human visitors, that is.
content: SOMERSET, England — It was one thing when deer began roaming around the grand house for the first time in decades and a family of weasels appeared on the banks of its moat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Sanders, M.D
title: His Sister Died 12 Days After Suffering Mysterious Spells. Now He Had Them.
description: The clock was ticking. An M.R.I., a spinal tap and blood tests weren’t revealing the culprit. Could it be psychological?
content: The 35-year-old man rose abruptly from the plastic chair in the waiting room at the Health Sciences Center Emergency Department in Winnipeg, Manitoba. He lurched toward the door, arms held stiffly before him as if warding off something only he could see. “I gotta get out of here,” he muttered. His eyes looked unfocused as he glanced at the family he didn’t seem to recognize. His mother hurried to his side. “It’s OK, Sean,” she murmured in his ear. “We’re here with you.” She took him over to his seat. And then, just as suddenly, he was back to normal, back to the man his family knew and loved.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Goldman and Alan Feuer
title: Proud Boys Leaders in Four States Are Charged in Capitol Riot
description: Prosecutors accused prominent members of the far-right nationalist group of conspiring together in connection with the Jan. 6 attack.
content: WASHINGTON — F.B.I. agents have arrested two organizers for the Proud Boys in Philadelphia and North Carolina, and prosecutors filed new charges against two other prominent members of the far-right group in Florida and Washington State as federal authorities continued their crackdown on its leadership ranks, three law enforcement officials said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe and Amelia Nierenberg
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Some sufferers of long Covid reported improvement after receiving the vaccine.
content: As we move into what may be the later phase of the pandemic, understanding long-term Covid symptoms is increasingly becoming a priority. Leading public health officials have warned that hundreds of thousands of Americans and millions of people worldwide may experience lingering symptoms — which can include monthlong fevers, breathing trouble, cognitive problems — that hamper their ability to live normally.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Coronavirus Reinfections Are Rare, Danish Researchers Report
description: People over 65 are more likely to experience a second bout with the virus, according to a large study of medical records.
content: The vast majority of people who recover from Covid-19 remain shielded from the virus for at least six months, researchers reported on Wednesday in a large study from Denmark.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow
title: Loop Loopers
description: Peter A. Collins spins a great Wednesday puzzle.
content: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — I always look forward to the midweek puzzles. I mean, I look forward to the puzzle every day, but the Wednesday and Thursday puzzles feel like a good gym workout. They’re just difficult enough for me to feel as if I’m having a good time, but not so intense that I know I’m going to regret it later.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sasha von Oldershausen
title: She Kept a Library Book for 63 Years. It Was Time to Return It.
description: “I think that says a great deal about how much we as a society value the written word,” a shocked librarian said.
content: A vintage children’s hardback turned up in the mailroom of the Queens Public Library in Auburndale recently. The book was “Ol’ Paul, the Mighty Logger,” by Glen Rounds, a collection of Paul Bunyan tall tales. According to the date stamped on the borrowing card inside, it was about 23,000 days late.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Losing a loved one to Covid has drawn some into politics.
description: Pamela Addison is, in her own words, “one of the shyest people in this world.” Certainly not the sort of person who would submit an opinion essay to a newspaper, start a support group for strangers or ask a U.S. senator to vote for $1.9 trillion legislation.
content: Pamela Addison is, in her own words, “one of the shyest people in this world.” Certainly not the sort of person who would submit an opinion essay to a newspaper, start a support group for strangers or ask a U.S. senator to vote for $1.9 trillion legislation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Das
title: Team New Zealand Retains America’s Cup by Beating Luna Rossa
description: A syndicate representing the Royal New Zealand Yacht Squadron won sailing’s biggest prize for the second time in a row.
content: For days, the Italian racing boat pursued its rival from New Zealand in the America’s Cup. Sometimes, the Italians looked for an advantage by cutting in as close as safety allowed. Other times, they veered as far away as the course allowed, seeking an edge by giving it rival a wide berth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Geneva Abdul
title: ‘I Had to Prove That I Exist’: Transgender Anchor Makes History in Bangladesh
description: Tashnuva Anan Shishir’s triumphant moment came after a long fight for equality that included harassment, bullying and suicide attempts.
content: When Tashnuva Anan Shishir was growing up in a conservative Muslim family in Bangladesh, she was ridiculed for behavior called too effeminate. She was often told she was mentally ill. The experience left her with one crucial question: “Who am I?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: As 4th Election Looms, Some Ask: Is Israel’s Democracy Broken?
description: Voters are heading to the polls in Israel for the fourth time in two years. And with few signs that this vote will break the cycle, many are already bracing for a fifth.
content: JERUSALEM — When an Israeli prime minister was investigated for corruption in 2008, he resigned after pressure from colleagues to avoid a conflict between his personal interest and that of the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley and Marie Fazio
title: President Biden: ‘I know Asian-Americans are very concerned.’
description: Mr. Biden said “the question of motivation is still to be determined” in the Georgia shootings, while renewing his concerns over a recent surge in violence against Asian-Americans.
content: President Biden said on Wednesday that “the question of motivation is still to be determined” in the Georgia shootings, while renewing his concerns over a recent surge in violence against Asian-Americans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: Trust in AstraZeneca Vaccine Is Shaken in Europe
description: The European Medicines Agency seems likely to pronounce the shot safe. But will anyone want to take it after this week’s panic?
content: PARIS — It’s said that the European Union grows stronger through crises. The bloc’s attempt at a coordinated vaccination program, less a rollout than a roller coaster, has tested that theory, and now the suspension of the AstraZeneca shots in many countries threatens to turn widespread disarray into an outright debacle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anemona Hartocollis
title: ‘When Normal Life Stopped’: College Essays Reflect a Turbulent Year
description: This year’s admissions essays became a platform for high school seniors to reflect on the pandemic, race and loss.
content: This year perhaps more than ever before, the college essay has served as a canvas for high school seniors to reflect on a turbulent and, for many, sorrowful year. It has been a psychiatrist’s couch, a road map to a more hopeful future, a chance to pour out intimate feelings about loneliness and injustice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Singer
title: Learning Apps Have Boomed in the Pandemic. Now Comes the Real Test.
description: Start-ups hope there’s no turning back for online learning, even as more students return to the classroom.
content: After a tough year of toggling between remote and in-person schooling, many students, teachers and their families feel burned out from pandemic learning. But companies that market digital learning tools to schools are enjoying a coronavirus windfall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber and Tara Siegel Bernard
title: Where’s My Stimulus Payment? Maybe in Your Account. (Finally!)
description: The latest round of payments are the biggest yet, and open to more kinds of dependents. But some hassles encountered in past rounds could show up again, and maybe new ones, too.
content: For the third time in less than a year, the federal government is sending stimulus payments to millions of Americans, no small logistical feat. But that doesn’t mean it will go smoothly for everyone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: What the U.S. Missed With Google
description: Newly revealed memos show that government investigators saw red flags in Google’s behavior nearly a decade ago.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: James Levine’s Final Years: A Timeline
description: The conductor’s last years at the Metropolitan Opera included a comeback, health woes and the sexual misconduct allegations that ended his career.
content: In the final years of his life, the conductor James Levine, who had shaped the Metropolitan Opera for more than four decades and who died on March 9, returned to his podium after a career-threatening injury; was eased out as music director after health woes made it difficult for him to fulfill his duties; and was fired from his new position as music director emeritus after multiple allegations of sexual misconduct with young men and teenagers surfaced.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: When Sweatpants Are Epiphanies
description: This is a teachable pandemic.
content: This article is part of Frank Bruni’s free newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it every Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: The Recall Effort and California’s Reopening Both Gain Steam
description: Wednesday: Gov. Gavin Newsom starts campaigning against the effort to recall him. Also: Spring is here.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Met Musicians Accept Deal to Receive First Paycheck Since April
description: The Metropolitan Opera offered its orchestra temporary payments of up to $1,543 a week in exchange for simply coming to the bargaining table.
content: The musicians of the Metropolitan Opera orchestra have voted to accept a deal that will provide them with paychecks for the first time in nearly a year in exchange for returning to the bargaining table, where the company is seeking lasting pay cuts that it says are needed to survive the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gillian R. Brassil, Alan Blinder and Kevin Draper
title: Tiger Woods Has Gone Home From the Hospital
description: Woods was hospitalized three weeks ago in Los Angeles after a car crash that left him with severe injuries to his right leg. Here is what we know.
content: Tiger Woods has been released from a Los Angeles hospital where he was treated after a car crash last month, according to a post on Tuesday to his Twitter account that said he was recovering at home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: How Wide Open Is the Best-Picture Oscar Race?
description: Each of the eight contenders has a path to victory, but it will be harder for some than others. For now, keep your eye on “Nomadland.”
content: What movie will win the best-picture Oscar, capping the most unusual year Hollywood has ever weathered? Eight films are left standing after Monday’s Oscar nominations, and though “Nomadland” is considered by most pundits to be the front-runner, an atypical awards season isn’t guaranteed to go with the expected winner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: Scientists Grow Mouse Embryos in a Mechanical Womb
description: Biologists have long held that a fetus needs a living uterus to develop. Maybe not anymore.
content: The mouse embryos looked perfectly normal. All their organs were developing as expected, along with their limbs and circulatory and nervous systems. Their tiny hearts were beating at a normal 170 beats per minute.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Schwartz
title: A Traveler’s Worst Nightmare: When Your Covid-19 Test Comes Back Positive
description: Contracting the coronavirus while far from home is a frightening possibility. And sometimes it happens, with consequences that can be deadly.
content: Late last year, Jose Arellano, a U.S. Navy veteran, and his wife, Gloria, traveled 2,000 miles from home to the resort town of Oaxaca, Mexico, to use up about $400 in plane tickets they had purchased at the start of the pandemic. The couple used masks, face shields and disinfectant, but not even a week into the trip, Mr. Arellano, 56, who had asthma, and then Mrs. Arellano, 54, began to get headaches and run a fever.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Christine Nofchissey McHorse, Navajo Ceramist, Dies at 72
description: Ms. McHorse used micaceous clay, a tensile material flecked with mica, to make sensual, mysterious work that called to mind the shapes of Brancusi. She died of the coronavirus.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Artifacts of the Lost Year
description: A fake fur box from Prada, a wood glider from Louis Vuitton. Suddenly, weird fashion kitsch has a whole new meaning.
content: The packages started arriving at my door last September: thick cardboard invitations to digital shows packed in tissue inside boxes inside shopping bags, sometimes nestled next to extra gewgaws like candy or buttons or candles, sometimes layered atop books. They were care packages from across the ocean and the city, Proustian madeleines meant to jog the memory and senses so that, sitting at our desks or beds or kitchen tables, wherever we “attended” the virtual fashion shows, we could imagine ourselves sitting on benches runway-side, as we once did.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: Biden Wants No Part of the Culture War the G.O.P. Loves
description: The generosity of his $1.9 trillion relief bill has the added benefit of shifting attention where he wants it.
content: The Biden administration appears to have adopted a two-pronged strategy to reduce the corrosive impact of hot-button social, cultural and racial issues: first by inundating the electorate with a flood of cash via the $1.9 trillion Covid relief act and second by refusing to engage fractious issues in public, calculating that deprived of oxygen, their strength will fade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Reeve Givens, Hilke Schellmann and Julia Stoyanovich
title: We Need Laws to Take On Racism and Sexism in Hiring Technology
description: Artificial intelligence used to evaluate job candidates must not become a tool that exacerbates discrimination.
content: American democracy depends on everyone having equal access to work. But in reality, people of color, women, those with disabilities and other marginalized groups experience unemployment or underemployment at disproportionately high rates, especially amid the economic fallout of the Covid-19 pandemic. Now the use of artificial intelligence technology for hiring may exacerbate those problems and further bake bias into the hiring process.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee
title: China approves a fifth Covid-19 vaccine.
description: The vaccine has several drawbacks. One is that it does not produce many T-cells, which help clear infected cells and prevent them from spreading.
content: China has approved its fifth Covid-19 vaccine, one produced by Anhui Zhifei Longcom Biopharmaceutical Co. and the Chinese Academy of Sciences. It was developed by a team led by George Gao, the head of the Chinese Center for Disease Control and Prevention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Lasky
title: $2.8 Million Homes in California, Connecticut and Washington
description: A John Lautner-designed showplace in the Hollywood Hills, a waterfront home in Darien and a contemporary house overlooking Puget Sound in Seattle.
content: John Lautner, who studied with Frank Lloyd Wright and designed some of the most celebrated houses in Southern California by following his teacher’s advice to “break the box,” created this diamond-shaped house in the Hollywood Hills for his bookkeeper, Lorena Deutsch. It sits on a ridge, on a dead-end street that runs parallel to a section of Mulholland Drive less than half a mile east of Runyon Canyon Park and about two miles northwest of the Hollywood Bowl.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: ‘Living Paycheck to Paycheck, Living Diaper to Diaper’
description: Diaper need causes more anxiety than food or housing insecurity for some mothers.
content: If your child is not potty trained, how many diapers do you have on hand right now? That’s a question I certainly wouldn’t have been able to answer with any specificity when my children were babies. But it’s a question that parents who struggle to afford the expense — about $70-$80 per month, per baby — can answer easily, because managing diaper need is among their most significant anxieties.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Fight for (and Against) a $15 Minimum Wage
description: After an increase failed to make it into the stimulus package, we look at the shifting political and economic arguments surrounding the issue.
content: The passage of the stimulus package last week ushered in an expansion of the social safety net that has been widely celebrated by Democrats. But one key policy was not included: a doubling of the federal minimum wage to $15 an hour.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Lemonides, Danielle Ivory, Mitch Smith, Bryan Pietsch and Eileen Sullivan
title: Massachusetts joins a growing number of states rapidly expanding vaccine eligibility, some exceeding Biden’s May 1 deadline.
description: The president has called on states to make all adults eligible by May 1 to get vaccinated against Covid-19.
content: Not long ago, Covid-19 vaccines were available only to the most vulnerable Americans and some essential workers. That is quickly changing as vaccine production and distribution ramp up and more states begin to heed a call from President Biden to expand access to all adults by May.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Israeli Researchers Show Dead Sea Scroll Artifacts
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, March 17, 2021.
content: “The archaeologists always used to chase after the robbers. We decided it was perhaps time to get ahead of the robbers.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: The High Costs of the Airline Bailouts
description: Federal efforts to prop up carriers saved jobs, but taxpayers likely paid big price.
content: Major U.S. airlines have received more than $50 billion in grants in multiple rounds of taxpayer-funded bailouts during the pandemic. As travel begins to rebound and the stock market cruises to record highs, Andrew asks in his latest column: Was the rescue worth it?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy Hass
title: An Emerald Pendant Plucked From a Designer’s Own Collection
description: To create a one-of-a-kind necklace, David Yurman accented a 31-carat, cushion-cut Colombian stone with a cascade of glittering diamonds.
content: David Yurman, originally a sculptor, founded his namesake jewelry business with his painter wife, Sybil, four decades ago. Their son, Evan, now 39, began collecting unique precious stones in his 20s. Already working for the family firm by then (he’d designed his first piece for the brand, a pair of cuff links, at age 11), Evan was obsessed with his rare gems — a 50-carat Kazakhstani spinel and a giant museum-quality opal from Lightning Ridge, Australia, among them. “My parents thought I was insane, paying that much for single stones,” he says. He never made them into jewelry, but a few years ago, when the family moved into high jewelry to complement its more accessible designs, Evan, now the chief creative officer, realized it was at last time to part with some of his treasures. So far, he has designed nearly 20 pieces using his private stash, including this white-gold diamond chain necklace with a 31-carat Colombian emerald pendant. He had the gem reconfigured into an antique cushion cut, which contrasts with the modern setting. “It’s vulnerable for me to let these stones go because they’re so personal,” he says. “When they’re gone, they’re gone.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stefanos Chen
title: New York Renters in Covid Hot Spots Are Four Times More Likely to Face Eviction
description: An analysis of court data shows that the areas hit hardest by the virus, largely Black and Latino neighborhoods, have the most eviction cases.
content: New York City landlords are seeking evictions nearly four times more often in the neighborhoods hit hardest by Covid-19 — predominantly Black and Latino communities that have borne the brunt of both health and housing crises since the virus swept the city last year, according to a new report.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Zagoria
title: Six Teams That Could Pull Off First-Round Upsets
description: Don’t count out the No. 9, 10, 11 and even 12 seeds.
content: For some people, the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament is the most exciting sporting event of the year. Sixty-eight teams from across the country battle it out over three weeks until only one remains and confetti pours down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: Indianapolis Man Killed 4 After Fight Over Stimulus Check, Police Say
description: A 7-year-old was among those killed. A man found hiding in a friend’s attic by a SWAT team is expected to face murder and robbery charges, officials said.
content: An Indianapolis man was accused of fatally shooting four people over the weekend after arguing with his girlfriend because he wanted a portion of her federal coronavirus stimulus check, police officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes
title: The Intelligence on Russia Was Clear. It Was Not Always Presented That Way.
description: A newly declassified intelligence report made clear that government agencies long knew of Russia’s work to aid Donald Trump, but he and allies muddied the waters.
content: WASHINGTON — Representative Jason Crow listened during a classified briefing last summer while a top intelligence official said that Russia was hurting Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s campaign to help President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: Judges Juggle Over 2,700 Cases Each as Families Wait for Day in Court
description: Short-handed and deluged by complex cases, New Jersey’s federal court is in a crisis. The backlog of cases has only gotten worse in the pandemic.
content: Phillip White, an unarmed Black man, died in police custody in New Jersey six years ago. After the Vineland, N.J., officers involved in the encounter were cleared by a grand jury and their own department, Mr. White’s family filed a $10 million wrongful-death lawsuit in federal court, accusing one officer of using excessive force.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: As Vaccinations Speed Along in Serbia, the Country Basks in the Glow of a Successful Campaign
description: The Balkan nation has Europe’s second-highest rate of inoculations after embracing vaccines from all suppliers, including Russian and Chinese.
content: BELGRADE — Stained for years by its brutal role in the horrific Balkan conflicts of the 1990s, Serbia is now basking in the glow of success in a good war: the battle to get its people vaccinated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: genial
description: This word has appeared in 105 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson
title: Hong Kong Quarantines a Few to Spare the Many. The Few Aren’t Happy.
description: Well-off expatriates account for the latest cluster, and hundreds of their contacts are in isolation. The city’s policies have helped prevent full lockdowns, but some say they go too far.
content: HONG KONG — A pandemic illness had struck Hong Kong, and the Worley family had gamely followed the rules. They wore masks. They socially distanced. They skipped traveling overseas with their newborn baby to visit his grandparents.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How can I check the status of my stimulus payment?
description: You can look up the status of your stimulus check on the I.R.S. website.
content: You can track the status of your payment via the I.R.S.’s Get My Payment tool. Be aware that the volume of users sometimes overwhelms the site.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio and Edgar Sandoval
title: Women of Asian Descent Were 6 of the 8 Victims in Atlanta Shootings
description: One man who was seriously injured called his wife before collapsing: “I’ve been shot! Please come.”
content: Delaina Ashley Yaun was looking forward to a date with her husband on Tuesday afternoon. The couple chose a relaxing massage at Young’s Asian Massage in a modest shopping center outside of Atlanta — a spa she had never visited before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Culture Wars Leave Biden’s Health Leadership Posts Vacant
description: Fights over President Biden’s nominees to lead the Department of Health and Human Services have centered on transgender policies, abortion and contraception coverage.
content: WASHINGTON — Nearly two months into the Biden administration, in the thick of the worst public health crisis in a century, the Department of Health and Human Services remains largely leaderless, with President Biden’s nominees to run the sprawling agency under concerted attack from Republicans over abortion and gender politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Susan Hodara
title: Shelton, Conn.: More Living Space and Lower Taxes
description: The up-and-coming city in Fairfield County is part suburb, part gritty downtown, with more residential and commercial development in the works.
content: When Kurt and Tamara Raschke started house hunting, they had two criteria: more living space and lower property taxes. They found both in Shelton, a city on the southeastern edge of Fairfield County, Conn., hugged by the Housatonic River.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What Are We Willing to Pay to Fight the Rising Sea?
description: A North Carolina community risks washing away, and solutions don’t come cheap. It very likely offers a glimpse of things to come.
content: As the ocean rises, homeowners in Avon, a tiny town on the Outer Banks of North Carolina, are confronting a tax increase of almost 50 percent to defend the only road into town. Residents want somebody else to pay for it; local officials say they’re on their own.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Weise
title: The Amazon Unionization Vote: What to Know
description: The unionization effort, which began last summer, is the largest and most viable organizing campaign among Amazon workers in the United States.
content: The most closely watched union election in recent history is underway in Alabama, where almost 6,000 workers at an Amazon warehouse near Birmingham are voting on whether they want to form a union. The election has attracted attention from President Biden, N.F.L. players and Hollywood actors, making it a high-stakes test of whether a union has a role in one of the country’s biggest employers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Gewirtz
title: These 10 Players Could Make or Break Your Bracket
description: The potential standouts in the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament bring a range of skills that could spice up the contest.
content: The N.C.A.A. tournament is full of exciting matchups, and these 10 players could lead their teams on a run or upset a bracket. Some are candidates for the John R. Wooden Award, given to the most outstanding player of the season, while others are anchors for their teams. They all promise to be fun to watch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Parker-Pope and Dani Blum
title: Double Masking Can Get Tricky. Here’s an Easy Way to Do It Right.
description: Two masks can increase your protection against the coronavirus. Just make sure you know the dos and don’ts.
content: As new, more contagious variants of the novel coronavirus spread around the world, public health officials are advising us to upgrade our mask protection. One of the easiest ways to do that is to wear two masks at the same time. Here are answers to common questions about the dos and don’ts of double masking.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: How to Clean Up Steel? Bacteria, Hydrogen and a Lot of Cash.
description: With climate concerns growing, steel companies face an inevitable crunch. ArcelorMittal sees solutions, but the costs are likely to run into tens of billions of dollars in Europe alone.
content: Few materials are more essential than steel, yet steel mills are among the leading polluters. They burn coke, a derivative of coal, and belch millions of tons of greenhouse gases. Roughly two tons of carbon dioxide rises into the atmosphere for every ton of steel made using blast furnaces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Nicholson
title: ‘Operation Varsity Blues’ Review: Failing the Ethics Test
description: Chris Smith’s gripping documentary looks deeper into the 2019 college admissions bribery scandal.
content: Pop quiz: Name the mastermind behind the 2019 college bribery conspiracy that sent the actors Felicity Huffman and Lori Loughlin to prison.
